speaker: James
text: [dry] North Africa appears weak, yes. But eighty-three million Egyptians in 2011, up from twenty-eight million in 1960. That's a demographic tidal wave, Elena.

speaker: Elena
text: A tidal wave of *people*, James, not inherently a threat. Their GDP per capita is barely $3,000. Poverty is the real issue, surely?

speaker: James
text: But the article highlights that combination: poor, young, rapidly growing populations, and food insecure. Historically, that's rarely a recipe for stability. For them, or for us.

speaker: Elena
text: So, your argument is the EU just... waits for the inevitable deluge?

speaker: James
text: [sardonic] That's one option. Or we consider the historical pattern. Remember the Vandals crossing into North Africa, then sacking Rome?

speaker: Elena
text: That was 5th century AD! Are you seriously equating modern migration with a Germanic tribe's invasion?

speaker: James
text: The *pattern* of population pressure leading to mass movement, yes. History Future Now has written extensively on how 'history rhymes'. Look at 'Crisis: Or An Explanation On The Origins Of The Decline Of The West'.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay, fine, historical parallels can be interesting. But predicting North Africans in Europe forming a 'swing political party' or resorting to 'aggressive rioting'... that's deeply alarmist.

speaker: James
text: [emphatic] The article says their family members are starving. That's an existential threat. What do people do when facing that?

speaker: Elena
text: They seek help, they seek asylum. They don't automatically turn into a political bloc bent on destroying European democracies.

speaker: James
text: But the pressure exists. And the article posits the 'moral nightmare' of stopping boats. What's the alternative when millions are trying to cross?

speaker: Elena
text: [frustrated] That's exactly the kind of thinking that backs us into a corner! We're talking about human lives, James. Not statistics.

speaker: James
text: Indeed. Which is why the suggested 'miracle' solution, 'Mediterranean Reunification', needs serious consideration.

speaker: Elena
text: Reunification? It sounds suspiciously like a new form of colonialism to me. 'Come into our free trade zone, but no free movement'.

speaker: James
text: Not colonialism. It's about bringing production closer, creating jobs *there*. Factories in Morocco, selling tariff-free into the EU. Better than buying from China, surely?

speaker: Elena
text: [thoughtful] Hmm. Substituting Chinese imports... that does make a certain kind of economic sense for Europe.

speaker: James
text: And it creates jobs for North Africans. Instead of us discussing 'China Has Many Of The Characteristics Of An Emerging Colonial Power', we'd be building a new Mediterranean economic hub.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay. I'll give you the economic upside for North Africa, and for Europe, if it really does mean less reliance on Asia.

speaker: James
text: And think of DESERTEC, powering Europe with Sahara solar. More jobs. Energy security.

speaker: Elena
text: That part, I like. A lot. It's genuinely collaborative.

speaker: James
text: Precisely. Shared prosperity, shared energy. A historical echo of the Roman breadbasket, but with solar panels.

speaker: Elena
text: But the 'strings attached' bit. Educating women to lower fertility. It feels... prescriptive, doesn't it?

speaker: James
text: It's a proven solution to demographic pressure. And it helps reduce reliance on Saudi-funded, more extremist schools, as the article notes.

speaker: Elena
text: I agree with the goal. But the phrasing makes me wary of cultural imposition. It needs to be genuine partnership.

speaker: James
text: It's about support, not dictation. Providing alternatives.

speaker: Elena
text: And the lack of automatic free movement? That's still a sticking point for me. If it's 'reunification', why not full integration?

speaker: James
text: It's a practical measure for now. With jobs created locally, the economic impetus to move would significantly diminish anyway.

speaker: Elena
text: It's hard to argue with the potential economic stability. I don't love the 'threat' framing, or some of the suggested limitations, but the idea of a shared Mediterranean economic future...

speaker: James
text: It's a bold vision. A chance to re-weave a common history, rather than just manage a crisis at the border.

speaker: Elena
text: Or create new tensions if it's not done right. A 'miracle' requires true partnership, not just European interests.

speaker: James
text: Indeed. It requires statesmanship. And for Europe to understand that its southern border isn't merely a boundary, but a shared destiny.

speaker: Elena
text: A destiny that feels a long way from the Roman Empire's grain shipments.

speaker: James
text: Perhaps. But the logic of proximity and mutual benefit remains.
